bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, 1941

div1.p: Kean discusses his health problems. Hendrick, in his Gorgas biography, made misstatements and did not correct them - it was Howard who advocated the use of kerosene to combat mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, 1941
div1.opener:
Washington D. C.
2804 N St. n.w Sept. 3, 1941
6 Inclosures
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
I have a lot that I would like to say
this morning if I had your good stenog-
but I am rather rocky from a two days spell
with the Old pump- It has now stopped its inter-
mitting and various irregularities and is going
steadily, but these spells leave me weak for a day
or too- I looked up Carter yesterday and am
sending you his own statement and his daugh-
ter's- If I said he was in Cuba from July 1st to
Sept. 1st it was in 1899 I was certainly mistaken if I wrote 1900 as you see,
from their letters- He left Havana July 23, 1900
on account of illness, so he could not have had
anything to do with the mosquito work. In looking
for these letters I came across my correspondence
with Mr. Burton J. Hendrick at that time Editor of The
World's Work and engaged in writing his Life of Gorgas
with Mrs. Gorgas as co-author- It was the mis statements.
in an advance chapter of this biography published in World's Work April, 1924 that caused me
to write, at the request of Mrs. Reed and of the Surgeon
General (Gen. Ireland) a letter to him correcting these errors
which I asked him to publish in his magazine World's
Work- He made a very unsatisfactory reply, which I
sent to Gen. Ireland with a copy of my letter- Gen. Ireland
Ac
K
2
sent the latter to the N. Y. Times & they printed it with the
reviews in the Sunday edition- Hendrick afterwards wrote
saying he would publish it, but retracted this offer when
I wrote him of Gen. Ireland's action-- This was in the spring of 1924
and the book did not appear until 6 or 8 months later,
but to our amazement there had been no correction
of these mis-statements- It was this letter published
in the N. Y. Times that Dr. L. O. Howard, the eminent
Chief of the Bureau of Entomology and a great friend
of Walter Reed, refers to in his letter which I inclose-
The Dr. Backeland to whom he refers is the famous chemist
see who's who
the inventor of Bakelite the first plastic I think- It
was Dr. Howard that taught us to use kerosene to fight
mosquitoes- I dont think that Gorgas knew anything
about fighting mosquitoes at until this G. O. no. 6
from Gen. Wood's Hdqrs was issued Dec. 21, 1900-
Now dont ask me for a copy for I dont know where
I would put my hand on one, altho. I wrote it-
Please return this letter after taking a copy of it-
I happened to be the Chief Surgeon at that time in place
of Col. Havard as he went on leave to the U. S. Nov. 19
1900 and returned Jan. 8, 1901- Why I was assigned
to take his place instead of Gorgas I do not now
remember if I ever knew, for Gorgas was my senior-
Well I have not yet begun to tell you what I started
out to write about, which is Gen. Truby's story of
3
the Episode of Walter Reed and Yellow Fever-
I am delighted with it and you will be also when
you read it- It is written in such a simple, direct
style which I think is charming and has so many
interesting details- I wrote him that the only thing
I was not satisfied with was what he had to
say about his own work- You will have to make
up for his modesty where you write your history.
Did he send you the other carbon copy? I hope
so- You will find many dates and details
that will delight you- When I began it I could
not put it down until I finished it- I am
going over it again carefully and will make notes
He has many dates which my diaries do not
contain and of course I have some that he lacks
I am going to put in with the inclosures to this letter
a part of a letter which came from Truby yesterday
which I think you should read but do not quote from
it in writing to him- The comments about the painting
are of interest- I do not send the first two pages
as they are about his daughter, who is expecting a
baby in Phila, and is the apple of his eye. The baby
arrived on the 27th- How the generations crowd along- The great
grandfather of this baby was Col. La Garde of the Medical Corps
of the Army & a warm friend of Gen. Ireland and me-
Please return all the inclosures after reading & noting-
